metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of Hydrometeorological observation network (an automatic weather station of Sidaoqiao populus forest station, 2013)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Hydrometeorological observation network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao populus forest station between 10 July, 2013, and 31 December, 2013. The site (101.124° E, 41.993° N) was located on a populous and tamarix forest (Populus euphratica Olivier. and Tamarix chinensis Lour.) surface in the Sidaoqiao, Dalaihubu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 876 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 28 m, north), wind speed profile (010C; 28 m, north), two four-component radiometer (CNR4; 6 m and 24 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 24 m, south, vertically downward), two photosynthetically active radiation (PQS-1; 24 m, south, one vertically upward and one vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), and soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02 and -0.04 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28 m; RH_28 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_28 m) (m/s), 24 m four-component radiation (DR_1, incoming shortwave radiation; UR_1, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor_1, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor_1, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn_2, net radiation) (W/m^2), 6 m four-component radiation (DR_2, incoming shortwave radiation; UR_2, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor_2, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor_2, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn_2, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_up and PAR_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), and soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm and Ts_100 cm) (℃).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. Data during 16 July, 2013 and 17 July, 2013 were missing during the malfunction of datalogger. The soil heat flux (G3) was missing during 20 November, 2013 and 8 December, 2013 because the wire was break by the sheep. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2013-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Is it necessary to employ quality control measures like removing data that exceed physical significance when collecting meteorological data in oasis–desert systems?
Are long-term observations crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas?

Disjunctive.Question: Are the data collection methods for hydrometeorological datasets in this field primarily based on automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, or scintillometers?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main components of a hydrometeorological data collection method used in oasis–desert systems?
Concept Completion.Answer: radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles

Concept Completion.Question: Where is a typical location for establishing meteorological observation stations in arid regions?
Concept Completion.Answer: middle and lower reaches of inland river basins

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure energy balance components in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used in oasis–desert ecosystems involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data with an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, along with hydrometeorological data observed from automatic weather stations at 10-minute intervals.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when collecting data on water vapor and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting data on water vapor and carbon exchange in arid regions is dealing with the degradation of the ecological environment, including drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and increased desertification, especially in inland river basins.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes soil and vegetation parameters for studying hydrometeorological processes in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, collected from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin in western China.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of the meteorological parameters measured in hydrometeorological observation networks?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, four-component radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are considered in the quality control process for hydrometeorological data?
Feature Specification.Answer: completeness of daily data (144 data points per day, every 10 minutes), specific code for missing data, removal of duplicate records, deletion of data exceeding physical limits or instrument ranges, marking of questionable data, standardized date and time format

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'eddy covariance system' in the context of hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. It is employed in oasis–desert systems to provide auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Definition.Question: How can 'ground-based measurements' be utilized in evapotranspiration estimation models?
Definition.Answer: Ground-based measurements can be utilized in evapotranspiration estimation models by using soil and canopy component temperatures observed via high-resolution thermal cameras. These measurements help partition ET into E and T by applying models like the Craig–Gordon model, providing inputs for the accurate calculation of soil and canopy component temperatures.

Definition.Question: What does 'data quality control' entail in the context of hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert systems?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control in hydrometeorological observations involves procedures such as data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. These steps ensure the accuracy and reliability of datasets, which include energy, water vapor, carbon exchange observations, and additional parameters such as radiation, soil heat flux, and vegetation and soil characteristics.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced during data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems versus strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis–desert ecosystems, challenges include maintaining ecological balance, handling the degradation of natural vegetation, and dealing with frequent dust storms. In strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, challenges are more focused on accurately estimating surface fluxes and dealing with the energy balance closure issues. Both systems face difficulties in effectively measuring energy and water vapor exchanges, but the specific environmental conditions and their impacts on data accuracy vary.

Interpretation.Question: How can the observed gaps in meteorological data, such as those caused by sensor malfunctions or environmental factors, be interpreted to improve the robustness of future data collection methods in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Observed data gaps, like those from sensor malfunctions or environmental interferences (e.g., animal activities), highlight the need for robust data collection methods that include redundancy and backup systems. Interpretation of these gaps can lead to the development of more resilient sensor networks and enhanced predictive maintenance schedules to minimize data loss.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the ecological balance of oasis-desert systems from long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, and how might these inferences guide sustainable development strategies?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes can infer the stability and resilience of oasis-desert systems, revealing trends in ecological health and productivity. These inferences can guide sustainable development strategies by identifying critical thresholds and informing resource management practices that balance ecological preservation with economic needs.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are accurate long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange critical in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurate long-term observations are critical because they provide a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges necessary for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. This understanding is significant for protecting ecological stability, supporting sustainable development, and achieving carbon neutrality goals in these sensitive ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can be expected from using high-resolution thermal camera data to improve the validation of evaporation and transpiration estimates in oasis ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution thermal camera data can lead to better validation of evaporation and transpiration estimates. This approach provides improved estimates of soil and canopy component temperatures, crucial for separating latent heat fluxes of soil and vegetation with reasonable accuracy. It enhances the TSEB model's ability to produce reliable estimates of energy partitioning in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, supporting more accurate assessments of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of implementing a rigorous data processing and quality control procedure on the reliability of long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a rigorous data processing and quality control procedure can significantly enhance the reliability of long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems. This ensures accurate data collection and archiving, minimizing errors caused by sensor issues or environmental factors. By maintaining high-quality datasets, researchers can better understand the interactions and stability of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, supporting sustainable oasis development and ecological security.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques impact the accuracy and validation of evapotranspiration measurements in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques improves the accuracy and validation of evapotranspiration measurements by providing better validation of evaporation and transpiration ratios. This method offers a more detailed analysis of energy and water vapor fluxes, particularly in arid regions with complex environmental conditions, enhancing the robustness of models like TSEB in estimating component fluxes and supporting precise energy balance assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting hydrometeorological data using an automatic weather station in the context of oasis and desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and sustainable development of the oasis.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to collect these long-term data to quantitatively understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for recognizing the interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting the socioeconomic development of oases.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in using thermal infrared cameras to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures for energy balance studies in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The steps include using a thermal infrared camera to capture radiometric temperatures of the surface, classifying visible and NIR images into soil and canopy pixels, extracting directional brightness temperatures, and converting these into radiation temperatures using long-wave radiation data and emissivity values. The estimated component temperatures are then validated against surface radiometric temperatures derived from incoming radiation measurements.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitate the accurate collection and validation of evapotranspiration data using the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The conditions that facilitate accurate data collection and validation using the TSEB model include the use of ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, high-resolution thermal cameras, stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes for validation, and eddy covariance (EC) systems to measure ET. The TSEB model's performance is enhanced by the accurate separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures, which are crucial for estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration ratios.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do methodological approaches in data processing and quality control enhance the reliability of datasets related to hydrometeorological observations?
Enablement.Answer: Methodological approaches in data processing and quality control enhance dataset reliability by ensuring consistent data collection, processing, and archiving. This includes handling data gaps, removing duplicate records, and excluding data that falls outside physical or instrumental limits. Quality control measures such as marking data with potential issues in red, standardizing date and time formats, and using consistent naming conventions further improve data reliability.

Expectation.Question: Why might datasets related to oasis-desert energy and carbon exchanges be limited in scope or availability?
Expectation.Answer: Datasets may be limited due to the challenging conditions of arid and semiarid regions, where long-term consistent data collection is difficult. Despite the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations, the complex interactions between oasis and desert systems, along with variable climatic conditions, make it hard to maintain a comprehensive dataset. Additionally, the focus on specific regions or limitations in data sharing and archiving practices can restrict the availability of wide-ranging datasets.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the effectiveness of using a combination of ground-based measurements and remote sensing data to enhance the accuracy of hydrometeorological observations?
Judgmental.Answer: Combining ground-based measurements and remote sensing data can enhance the accuracy of hydrometeorological observations by providing comprehensive coverage and detail. Ground-based systems like automatic weather stations offer high temporal resolution data, while remote sensing can cover larger areas and detect spatial patterns. However, challenges include ensuring data compatibility and dealing with limitations such as sensor precision and atmospheric influences on remote data.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the potential challenges in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems, given the harsh environmental conditions and technological limitations?
Judgmental.Answer: Data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems faces significant challenges due to harsh environmental conditions such as extreme temperatures, limited water sources, and potential equipment damage from sand and dust. Technological limitations include ensuring sensor accuracy and durability in these conditions. Moreover, the spatial heterogeneity of oasis–desert landscapes requires careful site selection and maintenance of equipment to ensure data reliability and representativeness.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can the current methodologies for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces be improved to address uncertainties in component temperature measurements?
Judgmental.Answer: Improving methodologies for estimating evapotranspiration could involve integrating more advanced thermal imaging techniques or refining the separation of soil and canopy temperatures to reduce uncertainties. Enhanced image classification algorithms and higher resolution data could improve the accuracy of component temperature measurements, addressing errors caused by misclassification and atmospheric effects. Additionally, continued refinement of models like the TSEB, with better parameterization and validation against diverse datasets, could enhance prediction accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the methods used for ensuring data accuracy and quality control in hydrometeorological datasets.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset processing and quality control involve ensuring daily data completeness, marking missing data with a specific placeholder, and removing duplicate or out-of-range records. Additionally, questionable data is marked for review, and data is formatted consistently with date and time in a single column.

Request/Directive.Question: Please detail the data collection methodologies used for hydrometeorological observations in arid oasis-desert systems, focusing on the equipment and periodicity of data collection.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field, hydrometeorological data were observed using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. These observations include radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. Additionally, data on the groundwater table were collected.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets in oasis-desert systems to improve understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets in oasis-desert systems include establishing more land surface flux and meteorological stations to capture diverse microclimates and ecological interactions. Implementing long-term observations and integrating auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters could enhance dataset comprehensiveness. Collaborative sharing of data through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center can facilitate wider access and integration of diverse data sources.
